content:
Cyanotic congenital heart disease: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention

Congenital heart defects affect 8-9/1,000 newborns. Among them, about 25% of children have cyanotic congenital heart disease. The disease needs to be detected early and treated properly to reduce the risk of future complications. This article is expertly advised by Dr. Vu Nang Phuc - Head of Congenital Heart Department, Cardiovascular Center, Tam Anh General Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City.

What is cyanotic congenital heart disease?
In children with congenital heart disease, one or more heart structures are abnormal (malformations). There are 2 groups of congenital heart diseases: (1)
Cyanotic congenital heart disease: This group includes heart defects that change the flow, causing oxygen-deprived blood to flow out to nourish the body. When a child is born with cyanotic congenital heart disease, the skin and mucous membranes often have a bluish color (due to insufficient oxygen in the blood), called cyanosis.; Non-cyanotic congenital heart disease: includes defects that do not affect the amount of oxygen supplied to the body.

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases are common
There are 3 types of cyanotic congenital heart disease: (2)
1. Obstructive lesions of the left heart
These congenital heart defects reduce blood flow between the heart and the rest of the body (systemic blood flow). Pathologies in this group include:
Hypoplastic left heart syndrome: is a condition in which the left side of the heart is very underdeveloped and cannot perform the normal pumping function. The cause is that the left ventricle is too small or non-existent. In addition, the left heart valves (aortic and mitral valves) do not function normally, leading to the main artery that carries oxygen-rich blood leaving the heart (the aorta) being smaller than normal. Therefore, the right side of the heart is responsible for pumping blood to the lungs, and the left heart has to take on the task of pumping blood to other organs.
Children with hypoplastic left heart syndrome need early surgery to avoid life-threatening complications.
Aortic arch rupture: The aorta is a large blood vessel that carries oxygen-rich blood from the heart throughout the body. Interrupted aortic arch is a rare condition in which a child's aorta develops incompletely or is interrupted. This means the heart cannot send blood through the aorta. If blood does not reach any part of the body, the child may go into shock and die.
2. Right heart obstructive lesions
This group of congenital heart defects reduces blood flow between the heart and lungs. Specific pathologies include:
Pulmonary hypoplasia: This is a heart defect that is often diagnosed soon after birth. In pulmonary stenosis, the valve that carries blood from the heart to the lungs (pulmonary valve) does not form properly. Instead of opening and closing to allow blood to pass from the heart to the lungs, this valve becomes blocked. So the blood cannot follow its normal path to get oxygen from the lungs. Instead, blood must reach the lungs through other natural pathways in the heart and nearby arteries.; Tricuspid valve atrophy: This disease occurs when the heart's tricuspid valve does not form. The normal tricuspid valve is located between two chambers on the right side of the heart: the right atrium (upper chamber) and the right ventricle (lower chamber). In children with tricuspid valve atresia, the heart has fibrous tissue instead of the tricuspid valve. This sheet of tissue blocks blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle – the normal circulation of blood.
Tricuspid valve atresia limits blood flow from the heart to the lungs, causing the right ventricle to be small and underdeveloped. In addition, another dangerous complication is lack of oxygen to the body's tissues. This condition is called hypoxemia.
Tetralogy of Fallot: This is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease, involving 4 heart defects: ventricular septal defect, right ventricular outflow tract obstruction, aortic overriding and right ventricular hypertrophy. These abnormalities make it difficult for the child's heart to provide enough oxygen to the entire body. Specifically, some blood without oxygen can enter the aorta and exit the body instead of going to the pulmonary artery to get oxygen.
Healthy heart and congenital heart disease Tetralogy of Fallot
3. Mixed lesions
The third group of cyanotic congenital heart disease is called mixed lesions. These heart defects cause the child's body to mix up pulmonary and systemic blood flow. Pathologies in this group include:
Transposition of the great arteries: This defect is the second most common cyanotic congenital heart disease. In it, the positions of the two main arteries leaving the heart (pulmonary artery and aorta) are reversed. The aorta is connected to the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery is connected to the left ventricle – completely opposite to the anatomy of a normal heart. At this time, oxygen-poor (blue) blood from the body returns to the right atrium, enters the right ventricle, then enters the aorta and returns to the body. Oxygen-rich (red) blood returns to the left atrium from the lungs and enters the left ventricle, which pumps blood back to the lungs – the opposite of how blood normally circulates.
Transposition of the great arteries is a critical condition and to survive, the newborn needs early surgery.
Abnormal total pulmonary venous return (TAPVR): In a baby with this heart defect, the pulmonary blood vessels (pulmonary veins) are attached to the wrong place in the heart. Normally, oxygen-rich blood travels from the lungs to the left atrium and then circulates throughout the body. In TAPVR, abnormal connection of veins sends blood through the right atrium, where it mixes with oxygen-poor blood.; Truncus arteriosus: Babies born with truncus arteriosus have only one main artery to carry blood to the body and lungs, instead of two separate arteries.

Common symptoms
Signs of cyanotic congenital heart disease often appear in the first few weeks of life but may not be noticed until the baby is older.
The main symptom of cyanotic congenital heart disease is the blue color of the child's lips, fingers and toes due to low oxygen content in the blood. This phenomenon can occur when the child is resting or active.
In addition, some children have respiratory problems (difficulty breathing), in which symptoms include:
Rapidly breath; Gray skin; Chest pain and fainting; Puffy eyes or face; Always in a state of fatigue; Slow weight gain; Sweating or crying while feeding; Weak pulse

Symptoms
Children with cyanotic congenital heart disease need to be diagnosed and treated early to prevent complications: (3)
Abnormal heart rhythm leads to sudden death; Pulmonary hypertension; Heart failure; Infection in the heart; Stroke; Dead

Cause of cyanotic congenital heart disease
Normally, hypoxic blood (blue blood) is sent to the right side of the heart to pump blood to the lungs for oxygen. The blood coming out of the lungs is oxygen-rich blood (called red blood). This flow of red blood continues toward the left side of the heart. From here, it is pumped throughout the body.
In children with cyanotic congenital heart defects, blood circulation through the heart and lungs is not normal, causing less blood to reach the lungs or mixing blue and red blood. This causes poorly oxygenated blood to be pumped out of the body, causing the child's skin to turn blue (cyanotic).
Risk factor
Babies are more at risk of cyanotic congenital heart disease if they have a family history of congenital heart disease. Some genetic syndromes considered to cause this disease include Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, Marfan syndrome and Noonan syndrome.
In addition, the following objective factors also increase the likelihood of cyanotic congenital heart disease in children:
Heart valve defects such as tricuspid valve, aortic valve or pulmonary valve defects;; Mother exposed to toxic chemicals during pregnancy;; Mother has an infection during pregnancy, such as flu, measles, rubella;; Mother has gestational diabetes but does not control blood sugar well;; Pregnant mothers arbitrarily use certain drugs that are harmful to the fetus;; Mother used drugs and abused alcohol during pregnancy.
Pregnant mothers with diabetes have a higher risk of giving birth to children with cyanotic congenital heart defects

Diagnostic method
Cyanotic congenital heart disease can be detected before a baby is born. If a routine fetal ultrasound shows a problem with your baby's heart, your doctor will perform a fetal echocardiogram. This paraclinical method will help identify cyanotic congenital heart defects as early as the 17th week of pregnancy. (4)
After the baby is born, if there is a suspicion of cyanotic congenital heart disease, the doctor will measure the oxygen level in the blood and perform laboratory tests such as:
Chest X-ray: to determine abnormalities in the heart's structure as well as diagnose whether the baby has lung problems; Electrocardiogram (EKG or ECG): measures the electrical activity of the heart; Echocardiogram: provides images of the valve structure and chambers of the child's heart; Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT) of the heart; Cardiac catheterization angiography
The baby had an echocardiogram to check for congenital heart disease right in the delivery room, Tam Anh General Hospital.

Treatment of cyanotic congenital heart disease
Treatment for cyanotic congenital heart disease depends on the severity of the disease. Commonly chosen methods include:
Cardiac catheterization: In this procedure, the doctor threads a catheter through a blood vessel in the thigh to the heart, then inserts an instrument to repair the defect. The cardiac catheterization method does not require opening the chest and performing surgery directly on the heart, so the child recovers quickly after the intervention.; Open heart surgery: This method is applied in cases that cannot be treated with cardiac catheterization. Congenital heart surgery can take place immediately after birth or several months or even years later. Children after surgery need to have their health monitored for life.
In severe cases, a combination of both cardiac catheterization and open-heart surgery may be needed to repair the entire heart defect.
Heart transplant: This is a method indicated for children with multiple heart defects of a complex nature, to replace the defective heart with a healthy heart from a donor.; Medication: Medication is prescribed based on the nature of the heart defect and the severity of symptoms.

Precautions
Cyanotic congenital heart disease occurs due to genetics and cannot be prevented. With objective causes, mothers can proactively prevent by:
Avoid using alcohol, tobacco and drugs during pregnancy.; Use medication during pregnancy according to your doctor's instructions; Be fully vaccinated before and during pregnancy, including influenza, measles, and rubella vaccines; Good control of blood sugar levels in case pregnant women have diabetes.; Consult your doctor about screening for genetic diseases (if necessary).
Fully equipped with modern facilities in fetal echocardiography, pediatric echocardiography, cardiac CT scan, pediatric cardiac MRI, interventional cardiac catheterization, pediatric cardiac surgery, Tam Anh General Hospital Cardiovascular Center diagnoses and treats and comprehensive monitoring of congenital heart disease for children from fetus to adulthood.
The center brings together a team of experienced experts, mastering advanced techniques such as stent placement of ductus arteriosus, occlusion of atrial septal defect, occlusion of ventricular septal defect, occlusion of ductus arteriosus, pulmonary valvuloplasty, and dynamic valvuloplasty. aorta, small-incision congenital heart surgery, endoscopically assisted open-heart surgery (MICS)... In particular, the Cardiovascular Center coordinates closely with other specialties such as Obstetrics, Pediatrics, Neonatology, and Diagnosis. Imaging, Endocrinology, Kidney - Urology... helps detect diseases early, heal children's hearts, giving them a healthy life.
Cyanotic congenital heart disease is a disease that can easily cause complications if not treated promptly. Therefore, screening for congenital heart disease during pregnancy and immediately after birth plays an important role in early detection and effective treatment of the disease. Children with cyanotic congenital heart disease, if treated early and properly, will have healthy hearts and develop physically and mentally like normal children.
